case_name: Samyukta Socialist Party v. Election Commission

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1653 of 1966 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 18, 1965 of the Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in Civil Writ No. 7011-D of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1653 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 18, 1965 of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in Civil Writ No. 701 1 -D of 1965.

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 193 of 1966 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution by Mr. Madhu Limaye for enforcement of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: AND Writ petition No. 193 of 1966. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Appeal filed by Samyukta Socialist Party through its General Secretary against Punjab High Court order dated November 18, 1965 dismissing Art. 226 petition filed by Mr. Madhu Limaye.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal has been filed, after obtaining special leave of this Court, I by the Samyukta Socialist Party, through its General Secretary, against the judgment and order of the High Court of Punjab, November 18, 1965, dismissing summarily a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution. The petition has been filed by Mr. Madhu Limaye, M.P., a member of the Samyukta Socialist Party.

facts.text: Both proceedings challenge Election Commission's allotment of Hut symbol to Praja Socialist Party, previously reserved for Samyukta Socialist Party.

anchor.surface_text: These two proceedings raise a companymon question and challenge the action of the Election Commission in allotting the Hut as the reserved election symbol to the Praja Socialist Party, which symbol was previously reserved for the Samyukta Socialist Party.

facts.text: Praja Socialist Party (PSP) formed by merger of Socialist Party and Kisan Mazdoor Praja Party (KMPP), recognized as national party after First General Election in 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The Praja Socialist Party  popularly known as the P.S.P.  was formed by a merger of the-Socialist Party and the Kisan Mazdoor Praja Party  known shortly as K.M.P.P.  and was recognised as a nationalist Party after the First General Election in 1952.

facts.text: Socialist Party recognized as State Party in Uttar Pradesh, Rajasthan, and Manipur after Second General Election in 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The Socialist Party was recognised as a State Party in Uttar Pradesh and Rajasthan and the Union Territory of Manipur after the Second General Election in 1957.

facts.text: In 1962 General Election, PSP recognized in nine States, Socialist Party in Uttar Pradesh, Rajasthan, Manipur; PSP got 12 Lok Sabha seats, Socialist Party 6; PSP 172 assembly seats in 9 states, Socialist 47 in 4 states.

anchor.surface_text: In the last General Election of 1962, the Praia Socialist Party was recognised in nine States and the Socialist Party in Uttar Pradesh, Rajasthan and Manipur. The Praja Socialist Party secured 12 seats in the Lok Sabha and 6 want to the Socialist Party., In the Legislative Assemblies the Praja Socialist Party secured 172 seats in 9 States and the Socialist Party 47 seats in 4 States.

facts.text: Merger of PSP and Socialist Party in June 1964 forming Samyukta Socialist Party (SSP).

anchor.surface_text: In June, 1964 there was a merger of the Praja Socialist Party and the Socialist Party and a new party, called the Samyukta Socialist Party, emerged.

facts.text: SSP contested four bye-elections and Kerala elections but seats deteriorated; union short-lived.

anchor.surface_text: The Samyukta Socialist Party companytested four bye-elections and the elections in Kerala but there was a deterioration in the total number of seats. The union, therefore, was short lived.

facts.text: On January 31, 1965, at inaugural meeting of National Ad Hoc Committee at Banaras, the two parties broke apart.

anchor.surface_text: On January 31, 1965, even at the inaugural meeting of the National Ad Hoc Committee held at Banaras the two Parties broke as under.

facts.text: PSP claims breakup restored pre-merger position; SSP claims merger final and continues despite defections.

anchor.surface_text: The Praja Socialist Party claims that this restored the position as it was before the merger while the Samyukta Socialist Party claims that the merger was final and the Samyukta Socialist Party as the united Party companytinues although some members have been guilty of defection.

facts.text: Before merger, PSP allotted Hut as reserved symbol, contested First General Election with it.

anchor.surface_text: Before the merger, the Praja Socialist Party was allotted the Hut as a reserved symbol and companytested the First General Election.

facts.text: After 1957, Socialist Party allotted Tree as reserved symbol in UP, Rajasthan, Manipur.

anchor.surface_text: After 1957 the Socialist Party was recognised as a Political Party in Uttar Pradesh and Rajasthan and in the Union Territory of Manipur and was allotted the symbol Tree which became its reserved symbol.

facts.text: 1962 elections fought with PSP-Hut, Socialist-Tree.

anchor.surface_text: The 1962 General Elections were fought with the Praja Socialist Party possessing the Hut and the Socialist Party the Tree respectively as their symbols.

facts.text: After merger, SSP allotted Hut as reserved symbol, Tree became free.

anchor.surface_text: Then came the merger. The Samyukta Socialist Party claimed and was allotted the Hut as its reserved symbol and the Tree became a free symbol again.

facts.text: After disruption, Election Commission on PSP's move took Hut from SSP and allotted to PSP, gave Tree to SSP.

anchor.surface_text: After the Party disrupted the Election Commission, on being moved by the Praja Socialist Party, took away the symbol Hut from the Samyukta Socialist Party and allotted it to the Praja Socialist Party, allotting at the same time the symbol Tree to the Samyukta Socialist Party.

facts.text: SSP challenged EC order via Art. 226 petition, dismissed by High Court, now in appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Election Com- mission was questioned by the Samyukta Socialist Party by a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution, and, on the dismissal of the petition, is questioned in the appeal before us.

facts.text: Notification S.O. 2316 dated September 19, 1961 allotted Hut as reserved to PSP in several states.

anchor.surface_text: The first of these Notifications was S.O. 2316 dated September, 19 1961. This showed that the Hut was a reserved symbol of the Praja Socialist Party in Andhra Pradesh, Assam, Bihar, Gujarat, Kerala, Uttar Pradesh, Madras, Maharashtra, Mysore, Orissa, Madhya Pradesh, West Bengal and the Union Territories of Delhi, Himachal Pradesh and Manipur.

facts.text: Notification S.O. 2939 of September 22, 1962 replaced previous, Hut reserved for PSP in some states, Tree for Socialist in others.

anchor.surface_text: This numberification was replaced by S.O. 2939 of September 22, 1962 and this time the Hut was shown as the reserved symbol of the Praja Socialist Party in Assam, Bihar, Gujarat, Kerala, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Mysore, Orissa and Uttar Pradesh. The Socialist Party enjoyed the Tree as the reserved symbol in Madhya Pradesh and the Union Territory of Manipur.

facts.text: On October 13, 1964, S.O. 3666 amended S.O. 2939 substituting Samyukta Socialist Party for PSP, giving Hut to SSP including Manipur.

anchor.surface_text: On October 13, 1964, amendments were made in S.O. 2939 by Notifica- 6 Sup. C. 1.166-13 tion S. 0. 3666 by substituting the name Samyukta Socialist Party in all items where the Praja Socialist Party was formerly mentioned. Against Manipur the name of Samyukta Socialist Party with the reserved symbol Hut was inserted in place of the Socialist Party and the symbol Tree.

facts.text: Final Notification issued on September 2, 1965 superseding S.O. 2939, allotting Hut to PSP in some states, Tree to SSP in others.

anchor.surface_text: The final Notification and the one which is challenged before us-was issued on September 2, 1965. It supersedes Notification S. 0. 2939.

facts.text: EC found original PSP leaders and bulk of members left united party, parties reverted to original state.

anchor.surface_text: But after enquiry, found it established that the original leaders of the Praja Socialist Party together with the bulk of the members of the Party had, in fact, left the united Party. The Election Commission ascertained the relative strengths of the Praja Socialist Party and the Samyukta Socialist Party before and after the breakup and came to the companyclusion that the Parties had reverted to their original state.

facts.text: EC restored Hut to PSP and Tree to SSP.

anchor.surface_text: The Election Commission, therefore, restored the symbol of Hut to the Praja Socialist Party as its original party symbol, and the symbol of Tree to the Samyukta Socialist Party as representing the old Socialist Party leaving it open to the Samyukta Socialist Party to choose any other free symbol if it liked.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds EC action within jurisdiction and supported by facts.

anchor.surface_text: We think the facts support the action of the Election Commission and also that it was within its jurisdiction.

facts.text: Secretaries of PSP and Socialist Party wrote to EC requesting Hut for united SSP, EC accepted.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdoubt that for a time the Praja Socialist Party and the Socialist Party did genuinely unite to form the Samyukta Socialist Party and that the Secretaries of the two Parties wrote to the Election Commission that the symbol Hut should be allotted to the united Party. The Election Commission recognised the new party and also accepted the request.
Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights. R. Gokhale and J. P. Goyal, for the appellant and peti- tioner.
dismissing summarily a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution. The petition has been filed by Mr. Madhu Limaye, M.P., a member of the Samyukta Socialist Party.

Under s. 169 of the Representation of People Act, 1951, the Central Government is empowered, after consulting the Election Commission,

anchor.surface_text: The Central Government has promulgated the Conduct of Elections Rules, 1961 and Rule 5 of these Rules makes provisions for symbols in Parliamentary and Assembly elections. The rule reads Symbols for elections in parliamentary and assembly constituencies.- The Election Commission shall, by notification in the Gazette of India

concepts.interpretation: Requires Election Commission to notify symbols that may be chosen by candidates and restrictions on choice; permits amendment of list and issuance of fresh notifications when circumstances change, such as party mergers or splits.

anchor.surface_text: Two questions arise-the first is What are the powers of the Election Commission in relation to the allotment of symbols, and the second is Whether in the circumstances, its powers were legally exercised ?

arguments.claim: EC action was bona fide, no malice or improper motive

anchor.surface_text: To begin with the action is bona fide, for no malice or any other improper motive has even been suggested.

arguments.claim: EC did not act capriciously or without jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether in doing so the Election Commission acted capriciously or without jurisdiction. We think the facts support the action of the Election Commission and also that it was within its jurisdiction.

arguments.claim: Restrictions in notifications permit amendment when circumstances change, parties unite or separate
EC action dictated by facts, not favouring one party over another

holdings.text: The Election Commission has powers under Rule 5 of the Conduct of Elections Rules, 1961 to specify symbols, impose restrictions on their choice, and issue/amend notifications when circumstances change such as party mergers or splits.

anchor.surface_text: Two questions arise-the first is What are the powers of the Election Commission in relation to the allotment of symbols... Rule 5 of these Rules makes provisions for symbols... The Election Commission shall, by notification in the Gazette of India

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 5 requires EC to notify symbols and restrictions; former rule explicitly allowed amendment, new rule implicitly does via restrictions analysis; circumstances like party changes necessitate updates.

holdings.text: The Election Commission's powers were legally exercised in the circumstances; its action restoring Hut to PSP and Tree to SSP was within jurisdiction, supported by facts, not capricious or arbitrary.

anchor.surface_text: We think the facts support the action of the Election Commission and also that it was within its jurisdiction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts showed PSP original leaders and bulk members reverted post-split; EC enquired relative strengths; action dictated by facts, consistent with rules permitting changes on circumstance shifts.

holdings.text: The Election Commission did not act capriciously or without jurisdiction in changing the symbol allotment.

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether in doing so the Election Commission acted capriciously or without jurisdiction. We think the facts support the action of the Election Commission

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts of party reversion post-breakup justified restoration; no malice, bona fide enquiry; within competency under rules unless arbitrary.

holdings.text: Changing Rule 5 by dropping the last 8 words did not deny the Election Commission power to amend symbol lists.
holdings.reasoning_summary: New Rule 5's restrictions framework still permits fresh notifications for changes; explicit amendment power not essential as circumstances dictate updates.

holdings.text: The Election Commission's action was bona fide, without malice or improper motive.

anchor.surface_text: To begin with the action is bona fide, for no malice or any other improper motive has even been suggested.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No suggestion of malice; based on impartial enquiry into party strengths and leadership post-split.

holdings.text: Arbitrary change of symbols by Election Commission would be outside its competency, as rules do not contemplate unfettered discretion.

anchor.surface_text: Although we are clear that a change of symbol by the Election Commission arbitrarily would be outside its competency, because the Rules framed by the Central Government and supplemented by the Election Commission in its Notification do not contemplate a discretion to the Election Commission

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules limit EC to fact-based changes via notifications/restrictions; no power to impose wishes arbitrarily.

holdings.text: The Election Commission has jurisdiction to regulate or restrict symbol choice and restore lost advantage to a party in cases of mergers/splits before final assignment.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules supplemented by notifications allow fact-driven adjustments; suitable for reversion after quick failed merger.

holdings.text: There is no force in the appeal; appeal dismissed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: EC proceeded correctly legally and factually; right conclusion reached.

holdings.text: Writ petition dismissed as covered by the same judgment; constitutional point not pressed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Same merits as appeal; no separate contentions pressed.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed with no order as to costs; writ petition dismissed as covered by common judgment
